qa_pairs.text_input: How can I ensure that my loved one is taking their medications correctly?
qa_pairs.output: Keep a list of all medications they take, including over-the-counter medications, dietary supplements, vitamins, and herbs. Bring this list with you to healthcare provider visits and ask any questions you may have. Give the right amount of medicine by asking the healthcare provider how much and when to give it. Lock up medications to ensure they are taken by the person they were meant for and are out of reach of children, teens, and older adults who could harm themselves.

qa_pairs.text_input: What should I do if I have questions about my loved one's health condition?
qa_pairs.output: It is important to educate yourself about the health condition to ensure that you can safely and effectively support your loved one. Read important tips on a variety of topics such as anxiety, healthy aging, diabetes, HIV treatment, heart health, osteoporosis, clinical trials, postpartum depression, and families of people with disabilities.

qa_pairs.text_input: How can I manage the emotional challenges of caregiving?
qa_pairs.output: Common challenges include emotional stress, balancing your personal life, and adapting to changing care needs. Remember to take time to care for your own health by scheduling your own well visits and screening tests, talking with your healthcare provider about feelings of depression and anxiety, learning how to manage caregiver stress, and preventing caregiver burnout by practicing self-care and seeking support and caregiving resources in your community.
